text:
You do look great, and
thank you for being here,

because I know you're very busy,
and we called you last minute.

Thank you for being
here today, too.
Well, sure.
I have to be here.
That's right.
Yeah.
That's right, it's your show.
That's right, it is.
So you posted.

You post a lot of things
about your workouts.

There's drinking
after your workout.
You work out and then you drink.
I work out with a trainer.

I will only work
out with trainer who
wants to celebrate afterwards.

So you-- you drink
immediately afterwards?
Sometimes during the workout.
Really?

It depends what
kind of mood I'm in.

If I don't feel like
moving out, yes a margarita
or some small vodka will help.
What time do you work out?

Sometimes in the morning,
whenever I feel like it, Ellen.
That's when.
Wow.
All right.

So this is what this
he makes you do.

That's me pushing
a sled up his hill.
Yeah.
Oh that's his hill.

That's his-- well we could
call it my hill, sure.
Right.

Oh and then you have to
control it the way down?
Oh there you go.
Oh, that seems harder.
That wasn't easy.
No.

No, and then how much
weight was on that?
Just my two tickets right here.

Each one of these
is about 10 pounds.

I don't even need
to I use weights.
You don't even need a sled.

Let's talk about
you're very political,

you're very outspoken about
what's going on in the world.
Did you see Trump on 60 Minutes?

I saw someone talking to
Leslie Stahl on 60 Minutes.

I mean I find it really,
really unsettling

that that's the
president of our country.

So I think it's so
important for us

to all, not only
just go and vote,

because I'm sure everyone
here is registered to vote,

I'm planning on
voting but there are

29 million Latinos
in our country that
are eligible to vote.

So it is so important that you
don't just register to vote,
that you go to vote.

So we can take our country back
for all the marginalized groups

that are suffering
under his thumb.
[APPLAUSE]
This is our country.

And even though the
news is just cyclical.

It's so depressing and
all of it is so upsetting.

There is a really beautiful
moment happening with groups,
with women coming together.

Finally women really holding
each other's hands and saying,
I don't care where you're from.

I don't-- getting rid of all
of those marginalized feelings

that we feel when we're in
a minority group that we

can't-- if our success, if we
succeed, it's a zero sum game.
The person next to us.

We all know now that
there's power in numbers,
and there's power collectively.

So is so important for
us all to just make

each other aware of what your
options are on voting day,

to lend your hand, to watch
over somebody else's kids
so they can go.

To give somebody a
ride to work if they
have to wait longer hours.

We all can just do
more than we're doing.
Just a little bit more.

I love that you've gotten
so-- have you always

been this political,
or is it just what's

going on now with the
climate that we're in today?
Or have you always been?
No.

I mean, Barack
Obama got elected.
I was like, this is great.
America is amazing.
We're not racist anymore.

And then I was like,
oh whoopsie, you know?

And then I thought
Hillary Clinton
was going to get elected.

I'm like, good, now
we're not sexist either.
And that didn't happen.

But what did happen was that
women came together and had

the most powerful
movement that's

going to be in history
books for the end of time.

And because as a
response to Donald Trump.

So there is a silver lining
to all of this mayhem.

And yes, I've always
been politically active,

but for me personally it felt
like an emergency situation.

And I feel like it's very
important if you have

a platform to use or to stick
your neck out for people who
don't.
I agree.
[APPLAUSE]

What is your take on the
Kavanaugh situation, with--
I mean I can imagine.
I mean I was outraged by it.

Well, it was
outrageous for a woman.

I mean first I saw her
testify, and I was like,
oh well that's it.
It's over.

And then he testified, I'm
like why is he testifying?

I mean, this is a single account
of what happened to this woman,

so he can counter it, but
he doesn't remember it.

Because he was
probably in a blackout.

And that's something
I do know a lot about.

And I watched it, and
I thought, oh wow,

this happened 30 years
ago with Anita Hill.
We all learned our lesson.

There's no way under
the sun that this
can happen in today's society.

And for it to happen
is just representative
of white male power to me.

It just looks like a bunch
of older white turtles

and men who are 85 plus saying
women, you don't get a voice.
And we have to say no to that.
Yeah I agree.
Just women in general have to--

that's how I think, and I
would hope most women are.

I would say all
women, but there are

a lot of women who still
are Trump supporters.
So you can't say all women.

But when that happened,
when he still--

I just felt like
it is time for us

now to really raise our
voices, and do something

about this before-- because if
that can happen, what's next?

What are they are going
to take away next from us?

I think we used to-- we always
have to look to black women.

Black women always vote
in their best interests.

94% of black women voted
for Hillary Clinton.

Well, 53% of white women
voted for that guy.

We have to look-- black women
vote in their best interests,
always historically.
They always know what's up.

And we have to be
sisters to them.

We have to vote in their
best interest as well.
Yep.
[APPLAUSE]

So this is bringing me to the
question about your Netflix

special, which is--
is it a documentary?

A documentary on
white privilege,

because I was looking around
a lot after the election

happened, and I was just
kind of looking at myself,

and I started to read
a lot of black authors

that I hadn't read
before, because I
was stuck in my own world.

And I just started to think
about all the privilege

I benefited from in this
industry specifically.
Being a Jew is a bonus.

Being a girl as a comedian when
I was coming up was a bonus.
There weren't a ton of us.

I had every advantage and
every door opened for me.

And when I started
to look around

people that don't have
as successful of a career

or are working twice as hard
to achieve the same things,

I started to feel really
gross about myself.

So on a very fundamental level
I wanted to examine it further,

and Netflix is great because
they're just, like, yeah go.

I'm like let's start with
my own white privilege.

I mean, I've just been
badly behaved for 20 years

and getting tons of money thrown
at me for being a loud mouth.

I mean you could
say I'm talented,

but you could also
say I'm not talented.

It's really neither
here nor there.

So for me it's an important
subject matter right now.

It's like what are the
people that are benefiting
from this going to do about it?

And I'm somebody who's
benefiting from it.

Good for you for doing
something about it.
Thank you.

Thank you, I'm glad I'm
doing something about it.
It's eye opening.

I mean I get in trouble
every single day I shoot.
I say the wrong thing.

I'm dying to know how
to be a better person.

So I think we can
all learn from it,

and I think white
people obviously
have a lot-- a long way to go.
Yes, we do.
Hi, I'm Andy.

Ellen asked me to remind you
to subscribe to her channel

so you can see more
awesome videos,

like videos of me
getting scared, or saying
embarrassing things.
Like ball peen hammer.

And also some videos of
Ellen and other celebrities.

If you're into
that sort of thing.
Yah!
[BLEEP] God [BLEEP]
